Key Arguments: The definitions of misinformation, disinformation, and serious harm are subjective and inadequate.
The legislation risks stifling genuine critique of government actions and hindering debates on controversial topics.
The Bill could lead to suppression of minority voices and political dissent.
The proposed penalties are too high and could lead to self-censorship by digital service providers.
The Bill could result in an erosion of a free and open society by encouraging self-censorship among the public.
Notable Quotes: Managing misinformation means to manage the voices of those who do not conform to the accepted narrative.
The definitions of 'misinformation', 'disinformation' and 'serious harm' are inadequate due to the high level of subjectivity involved.
The proposed penalties are far too high. The magnitude of these penalties risks creating an atmosphere of self-censorship amongst digital service providers.
